thread.title: 10Best: Places to enjoy the Appalachian Trail in a day
thread.title_full: 10Best: Places to enjoy the Appalachian Trail in a day

title: 10Best: Places to enjoy the Appalachian Trail in a day
text:
The historic town of Harpers Ferry, W.Va., is home to the Appalachian Trail Conservancy headquarters. Many hikers stop at the visitors' center to pose for a picture on the porch, making it one of the top three photographed places on the trail. Appalachian Trail Conservancy Fullscreen Hiker Dave "Taco" Tachon pauses on his Appalachian Trail hike as he passes through Shenandoah National Park in Virginia. Dave Tachon, Appalachian Trail Conservancy Fullscreen The Appalachian Trail passes through Maryland's Gathland State Park, which includes remains of the estate of George Alfred Townsend, a correspondent during the Civil War who wrote under the pen name "Gath." Several buildings remain on the estate, including the War Correspondents Memorial Arch. Tourism Council of Frederick County Fullscreen When the Appalachian Trail reaches Mount Greylock, the highest point in Massachusetts, hikers are at 3,491 feet and passing through a landscape that inspired literary giants like Nathaniel Hawthorne, Henry David Thoreau and Herman Melville. Berkshire Visitors Bureau Fullscreen Appalachian Trail hikers celebrate when they reach Mount Washington State Park, N.H., the highest point in New England, which offers the possibility of storms and snow year-round. David Rough, Appalachian Trail Conservancy Fullscreen The Appalachian Trail travels down the main street of tiny Hot Springs, N.C. VisitNC.com Fullscreen The Appalachian Trail marks its lowest point as it passes through New York's Bear Mountain State Park and the Trailside Museums and Zoo. Mike Adamovic Fullscreen In Pennsylvania, the Appalachian Trail passes through Boiling Springs, a small community with easy hikes past farm fields and around picturesque Children's Lake. Crystal Hunt Fullscreen Clingmans Dome in Great Smoky Mountains National Park is the highest point on the Appalachian Trail. National Park Service Hiker Dave "Taco" Tachon pauses on his Appalachian Trail hike as he passes through Shenandoah National Park in Virginia. (Photo: Dave Tachon, Appalachian Trail Conservancy)
684 CONNECT 143 TWEET 13 LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE You don’t have to be a gung-ho hiker to see the Appalachian Trail, which is attracting new interest thanks to the film A Walk in the Woods , starring Robert Redford and Nick Nolte. The 2,190-mile path is easily accessible and beautiful in autumn colors, says Laurie Potteiger of the Appalachian Trail Conservancy . “There are places of beauty, history and inspiration. And you know if you step out in one direction, those blazes will lead you to Maine, and the other way to Georgia.” While the trail has made news recently due to rowdy celebrations by through-hikers who complete the entire length, the path has long been revered for beauty and solitude. Potteiger shares some highlights with Larry Bleiberg for USA TODAY.
Hot Springs, N.C.
The trail passes down the main street of this tiny town – look for the “AT” diamond symbols in the sidewalk. “You really get the sense of being in a charming Appalachian Trail town. It’s surrounded by mountains,” Potteiger says. Hikers can follow the French Broad River for a short distance, and then climb to a rocky outcropping called Lover’s Leap. hotspringsnc.org
Clingmans Dome, Great Smoky Mountains National Park, Tenn. and N.C.
An observation deck tops the highest point on the Appalachian Trail, offering a 360-degree view of Great Smoky Mountains National Park. “It’s a big long spiral ramp that brings you above the treetops. You’re surrounded by mountains as far as the eye can see,” Potteiger says. Although in an otherwise remote part of the park, the spot on the Tennessee-North Carolina line is easily accessible from a seasonal road and paved walkway. nps.gov/grsm
Shenandoah National Park, Va.
Skyline Drive, Shenandoah National Park’s famed scenic highway, crosses the multi-state route more than 30 times, making it easy to see hikers at overlooks or a trail exhibit at the visitors’ center. “There are many ways to connect with the trail here,” Potteiger says. The park, which is the place through-hikers are most likely to see wildlife, offers short nature paths, along with lodge-to-lodge hikes. nps.gov/shen
Harpers Ferry, W.Va.
Not only was this historic town the scene of John Brown’s Raid and failed slave revolt, but it’s also home to the Appalachian Trail Conservancy headquarters. Most through-hikers stop at the visitors’ center to pose for a picture on the porch. “The front of our stone-and-stucco building is one of the top three places on the Appalachian Trail that’s photographed,” Potteiger says. appalachiantrail.org
Gathland State Park, Md.
This quiet gap once saw action in the Civil War Battle of South Mountain. It’s now home to a war correspondents memorial, created by a journalist who covered the conflict. “It’s a tiny park with a slice of history, and an easy way to have a little introduction to the Appalachian Trail,” Potteiger says. dnr2.maryland.gov/publiclands
Boiling Springs, Pa.
Visitors to this small community find bucolic scenery with easy hikes past farm fields and around picturesque Children’s Lake. “It’s a calm quiet place to take a stroll on the edge of the Cumberland Valley,” Potteiger says. The town is also home to the Appalachian Trail Commission’s regional office and visitors’ center. appalachiantrail.org
High Point State Park, N.J.
The aptly named site has the highest elevation in the state at 1,803 feet, showing the wild side of the country’s most urban state and offering views of the Pocono and Catskill mountains. “The hike (to reach the summit) is just a very short distance,” Potteiger says. njparksandforests.com
Trailside Museums and Zoo, Bear Mountain State Park, N.Y.
The Trail marks its lowest point as it passes by the Hudson River and straight through this park and zoo. A drive, or steep climb, reaches the mountain top, with sweeping views of the Hudson River Valley. “You’re a relatively short distance from New York City,” Potteiger says. nysparks.com/parks/13/details.aspx
Mount Greylock State Reservation, Mass.
When hikers reach this summit, the highest point in Massachusetts, they’re at 3,491 feet and passing through a landscape that inspired literary giants like Nathaniel Hawthorne, Henry David Thoreau and Herman Melville. Visitors can drive to an observation tower, but Potteiger says some like to hike the mountain. “It’s quite a climb with quite an elevation gain.” mass.gov/eea/agencies/dcr
Mount Washington State Park, N.H.
The highest point in New England offers the possibility of storms and snow year-round. “The combination of being so far north and the extreme elevation makes it famous for having multiple weather patterns converge as one,” Potteiger says. “Trees cannot grow here.” But visitors have other ways to get the view: A road and cog railway also go to the peak. nhstateparks.org
